sections.content: In this lesson, we'll explore the modules that support inventory management and financial processes in Zoho CRM. These modules work together to track products, manage vendor relationships, generate quotes and invoices, and maintain accurate inventory levels.
**Products** refer to the goods or services sold or procured by any organization. The Products module serves as your central catalog for everything your business offers.

items: What are products for? How can they be used within the CRM?
What information should be tracked for each product?
How do products connect to other modules like Deals, Quotes, and Invoices?

sections.content: When viewing products in the demo, note important fields such as:

items: **Product Name** - The name of your product or service
**Stock Number (Quantity in Stock)** - Current inventory level
**Unit Price** - The price per unit
**Product Code/SKU** - Unique identifier for the product
**Product Category** - Classification for organization
**Description** - Detailed information about the product

sections.content: Important: We will be illustrating inventory management with the Stock number later in this lesson, and demonstrating how other modules can affect inventory levels automatically.
**Hands-On Exercise:** Create 5 different products relevant to your business in the Products module. Include:

items: Product name and description
Unit price
Quantity in stock
Product code or SKU
Any other relevant details specific to your business

sections.content: Think about the actual products or services your organization offers, and create realistic entries that you could use in practice.

**Vendors** are the companies, individuals, or contractors from whom your organization procures products and/or services. The Vendors module functions similarly to the Accounts module, but specifically for managing your supply chain relationships.

items: **Vendors** represent the company or organization you purchase from
**Contacts** can be linked to Vendors to show representatives or employees of that Vendor
This maintains the relationship hierarchy for your procurement processes
Products can be associated with Vendors to track which suppliers provide which items

sections.content: Activity: Create Vendors and Link Products
**Hands-On Exercise:** To explore how Vendors work with Contacts and Products in CRM:

items: Create at least 2 Vendors in your CRM
Add vendor details such as company name, address, phone, and email
Link the vendors to the products you created earlier
Optionally, create Contacts associated with these Vendors (e.g., sales representatives, account managers)

sections.content: This establishes the connection between your product catalog and your supplier relationships.
**Quotes** are legal agreements between a customer and a vendor to deliver the requested product within the specified time at the agreed-upon price.

items: Quotes provide an estimate of Products totaled up in a **subform**
Products are added line-by-line to build the complete quote
Inventory templates compile this information into a typical Quote format with line items
Quotes can be sent directly to customers from the CRM
The quote automatically links to the associated Deal, Contact, and Account

sections.content: Activity: Create a Quote and Convert to Invoice

items: Navigate to a Deal in your CRM (or create a new one)
Create a Quote for that Deal
Add Products to the Quote using the products you created earlier
Review the Quote total and details
Convert the Quote to an Invoice
Mark the Invoice status as **'Delivered'**
Observe what happens to the **'Quantity in Stock'** for the Products you added

sections.content: Alternative: If there is limited time, the instructor will demonstrate the full process: creating a Quote, converting to Invoice, marking as Delivered, and showing the automatic inventory subtraction in the Products module.

**Invoices** are bills issued by the vendor to customers along with the goods or services for the purpose of receiving payment. Invoices represent the formal request for payment after a sale is confirmed.
Similar to Purchase Orders, Invoices have a direct impact on inventory:

items: When an Invoice Status is marked as **'Delivered'**, the system automatically updates inventory
The **Quantity** specified in the Invoice subform is **subtracted** from the **Stock number** (Quantity in Stock) of each Product
This ensures real-time inventory tracking as sales are completed
You can view the updated stock levels immediately in the Products module

sections.content: **Demo:** The instructor will demonstrate creating an Invoice, marking it as Delivered, and showing the automatic inventory deduction for the same product used in previous examples.
**Sales Orders** are confirmation of sales, generated after the customer sends a purchase order based on your quotes.
The use of Sales Orders depends on your business process:

items: Once a Deal is finalized, you might create a Sales Order as an intermediate step
Alternatively, you might go directly from Quote to Invoice
Some businesses require Sales Orders for internal approval processes
Others use Sales Orders when there's a gap between order confirmation and fulfillment
The workflow depends on how your business conducts this part of a sale

sections.content: Sales Orders serve as the bridge between the customer's commitment to purchase (often formalized in their Purchase Order to you) and your Invoice for payment.
**Purchase Orders** are legally binding order-placement documents for procuring products or services from vendors. These are orders **you place with your suppliers** to restock inventory.
Purchase Orders have the **opposite effect** on inventory compared to Invoices:

items: Create a Purchase Order when ordering products from a Vendor
Note the **'Quantity'** field within the subform for each product
When Purchase Orders are marked with Status **'Delivered'**, inventory is updated automatically
The Quantity from the Purchase Order subform is **added to** the Stock number in the Products module
This tracks incoming inventory from your vendors
Creating a Purchase Order associated with a Vendor
Adding products with specified quantities
Marking the Purchase Order status as 'Delivered'
Showing the automatic inventory increase in the Products module

sections.content: Key Concept: Invoices **subtract** from inventory (products going out to customers), while Purchase Orders **add to** inventory (products coming in from vendors). This creates a complete inventory management system within CRM.
**CPQ** stands for Configure, Price, Quote. This advanced feature set helps sales teams create complex quotes more efficiently and accurately.

items: **Connect products together** to be added to a subform automatically
**Suggest products** in relation to items that have previously been added (cross-selling and upselling)
**Allow sales people to narrow down subform items** based on their criteria
**Automate pricing rules** based on quantity, customer type, or other factors
**Guide sellers** through the quoting process with conditional logic

sections.content: The Product Configurator allows you to build bundles or packages of products that are commonly sold together. When a sales rep selects one product, related products can be automatically added or suggested.

Price Rules differ from Product Configurators in their purpose. While Product Configurators focus on *which* products to include, Price Rules determine *how much* to charge based on conditions such as:

items: Quantity discounts (bulk pricing)
Customer type or tier
Time-based promotions
Product combinations
Custom business logic

sections.content: The builder interface for Price Rules is similar to the Product Configurator, making it easy to create complex pricing logic.

Guided Selling walks sales representatives through a series of questions to determine which products best fit the customer's needs. Based on their answers, the system suggests appropriate products and configurations.
During this demonstration, the instructor will show:

items: **Product Configurator** - Building a product bundle and executing the automation live
**Price Rules** - Reviewing a premade example of conditional pricing (the builder is the same as Product Configurator)
**Guided Selling** - Using a GIF example from the Zoho Knowledge Base or a demo account setup to show the customer-facing experience

sections.content: These CPQ features significantly reduce quote preparation time, minimize errors, and ensure consistent pricing across your sales team.
The inventory and finance modules work together to create a complete business management system:

items: **Products** - Your central catalog of goods and services
**Vendors** - Companies you purchase from to restock inventory
**Purchase Orders** - Orders placed with vendors (adds to inventory when delivered)
**Quotes** - Proposals sent to customers
**Sales Orders** - Confirmation of customer orders (optional step)
**Invoices** - Bills sent to customers (subtracts from inventory when delivered)
**CPQ** - Tools to streamline and automate the quoting process

sections.content: This integrated approach ensures accurate inventory tracking, streamlined sales processes, and better financial management within your CRM.
